item.title: Huawei Executive Took Part in Sanctions Fraud, Prosecutors Say - The New York Times
item.description:
Huawei Executive Took Part in Sanctions Fraud, Prosecutors Say  The New York Times

VANCOUVER, British Columbia ‚Äî The reasons that the United States asked the Canadian authorities to arrest a top executive of the Chinese technology company Huawei last week had been shrouded in mystery. On Friday, the details of the arrest and what led up to it came out in a Canadian courtroom. At a bail hearing in Vancouver for Meng Wanzhou, the chief financial officer of Huawei and a daughter of the company‚Äôs founder, Canadian prosecutors said she was accused of fraud. The heart of the charges related to how Ms. Meng may have participated in a scheme to trick financial institutions into m...

item.title: Meng Wanzhou Was Huawei‚Äôs Professional Face, Until Her Arrest - The New York Times
item.description:
Meng Wanzhou Was Huawei‚Äôs Professional Face, Until Her Arrest  The New York Times

BEIJING ‚Äî As Huawei‚Äôs finance chief and daughter of its founder, Meng Wanzhou has been a polished, professional face for a huge technology firm that long was opaque to the outside world. Ms. Meng, the eldest daughter of Ren Zhengfei, the leader of the telecom equipment maker, has appeared before reporters to announce the company‚Äôs financial results. She has spoken at company events in New York; Canc√∫n, Mexico; and beyond. She helped inaugurate centers in Britain, a key market for the Chinese giant‚Äôs expansion into the Western world. She also sat on the board of a Huawei partner company in H...

item.title: Huawei seeks to recover from espionage concerns with $2 billion spending pledge - The Telegraph
item.description:
Huawei seeks to recover from espionage concerns with $2 billion spending pledge  The Telegraph

Huawei has pledged to spend an extra $2bn (¬£1.5bn) to ease concerns raised by British intelligence agency GCHQ over the potential security risk posed by the use of its equipment in the UK‚Äôs telecom networks The spending pledge is designed to fix technical concerns over Huawei‚Äôs hardware. A government report published in July found that ‚Äúshortcomings in Huawei‚Äôs engineering processes have exposed new risks in the UK telecommunication networks.‚Äù Huawei will use the money to improve its production processes in order to allow the government to inspect its devices more easily. The spending pledg...

item.title: üá®üá≥Huawei CFO‚Äôs arrest rattles investors, markets tumble l Al Jazeera English - Al Jazeera English
item.description:
üá®üá≥Huawei CFO‚Äôs arrest rattles investors, markets tumble l Al Jazeera English  Al Jazeera English

American stocks clawed back much of the ground lost in an early plunge triggered by the news of the arrest of Huawei Technologies CFO, Meng Wanzhou, in Canada at the United States‚Äô request. The initial drop joined a global rout, reviving worries over trade tensions. Meng‚Äôs arrest threatens to drive a wedge between the US and China just days after they agreed on a 90-day trade-war truce in Argentina on Saturday. Al Jazeera's Kristen Saloomey reports. - Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www....

item.title: Huawei's Meng charged with conspiracy to defraud banks - The Telegraph
item.description:
Huawei's Meng charged with conspiracy to defraud banks  The Telegraph

Huawei's chief financial officer has been charged with conspiracy to defraud US banks. The company broke US sanctions by doing business in Iran using an unofficial subsidiary, a Canadian court was told on Friday. Its chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou was arrested in the country last week and is wanted in the US over "fraud offences", Vancouver Law Courts heard. The US alleges that Huawei used a subsidiary, Skycom, to do business with Iran, bypassing US sanctions. Ms Meng allegedly misled US financial institutions by telling them that Skycom and Huawei were separate companies, putting the...

item.title: Huawei pledges $2bn in effort to allay UK security concerns - The Guardian
item.description:
Huawei pledges $2bn in effort to allay UK security concerns  The Guardian

The Chinese telecoms giant Huawei is to spend $2bn (¬£1.5bn) in an effort to alleviate British security services‚Äô concerns about vulnerabilities in its products, capping a torrid week for the firm. In July, a British government centre established to verify the integrity of Huawei‚Äôs technology warned that it had security concerns about the company‚Äôs technology and could only provide ‚Äúlimited assurance‚Äù that risks to national security had been mitigated. On Thursday BT confirmed it was removing Huawei equipment from key areas of its 4G network over concerns about the Chinese firm‚Äôs presence in...

item.title: Huawei finance chief Meng Wanzhou to appear in court as Chinese media react furiously to arrest - The Independent
item.description:
Huawei finance chief Meng Wanzhou to appear in court as Chinese media react furiously to arrest  The Independent

Huawei‚Äôs finance chief is set to appear at a bail hearing in Vancouver on Friday amid a backlash in Chinese media over her detention. Chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou, daughter of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei, was arrested by Canadian authorities on Saturday at the request of the US government which is seeking extradition. No official reason has been given but it is thought to be linked to alleged violations of US sanctions on Iran. Stock markets calmed on Friday following a tumultuous session on Thursday as news of Ms Meng‚Äôs detention prompted fears of a new front on the US-China trade ...

Chinese company Huawei‚Äôs involvement in a ¬≠proposed undersea internet cable near Sydney has sparked fresh espionage ¬≠concerns, as a US-led backlash against the telco escalated yesterday following the arrest of one of its top executives. Huawei chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou was arrested in Canada, at the ¬≠request of the US government, ¬≠allegedly for ¬≠sanction-busting ¬≠behaviour towards Iran. item.title: US case against Huawei CFO revealed in Canadian court - CNN
item.description:
US case against Huawei CFO revealed in Canadian court  CNN

The United States is claiming that the chief financial officer of Chinese tech giant Huawei covered up violations of sanctions on Iran, according to Canadian prosecutors. Meng Wanzhou, who was arrested in Vancouver and faces extradition to the United States, is believed to have helped Huawei circumvent US sanctions by telling financial institutions that a Huawei subsidiary was a separate company, prosecutors said at a hearing Friday to determine whether Meng should be released on bail. Her lawyer said that she has ties to Canada and is not a flight risk. The judge, after hearing arguments f...

Meng Wanzhou, also known as Sabrina Meng and Cathy Meng, is the chief financial officer and deputy chairwoman of the board of Chinese tech firm Huawei. ¬©2018 Cable News Network, Inc. A WarnerMedia Company. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Europe should be wary of Huawei, EU tech official says - Reuters
item.description:
Europe should be wary of Huawei, EU tech official says  Reuters

The European Union should be worried about Huawei [HWT.UL] and other Chinese technology companies because of the risk they pose to the bloc's industry and security, the EU's technology chief said on Friday, echoing concerns raised elsewhere in the world. Huawei expressed disappointment at EU tech commissioner Andrus Ansip's comments, saying it had never been asked to install technology that could be used for spying and never would. "Do we have to be worried about Huawei or other Chinese companies? Yes, I think we have to be worried about those companies," Ansip told a news conference in Bru...

item.title: Ericsson sorry for software glitch that hits mobile services in Britain and Japan - Reuters
item.description:
Ericsson sorry for software glitch that hits mobile services in Britain and Japan  Reuters

Sweden's Ericsson (ERICb.ST: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz) apologized and said it was working hard to fix a software glitch that was responsible for millions of smartphone users in Britain, Japan and other countries losing internet access on Thursday. O2 (TEF.MC: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz), Britain's second biggest network, and Japan's Softbank (9984.T: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz), both Ericsson customers, reported outages on their 4G networks earlier on Thursday. The mobile network equipment maker confirmed that a problem with its software was to blame for the ...

item.title: What is Huawei, and why the arrest of its CFO matters - CNN
item.description:
What is Huawei, and why the arrest of its CFO matters  CNN

The arrest of a top Huawei executive has roiled the business world and threatens to derail the tenuous trade truce between the United States and China. Meng Wanzhou, the Chinese tech company's chief financial officer, was detained in Vancouver on Saturday at the request of US authorities. She's accused by the United States of helping Huawei cover up violations of sanctions on Iran, according to Canadian prosecutors. US lawmakers are condemning Huawei, which they say poses a national security threat to the United States. Chinese officials have called for Meng's release. An op-ed in the Chine...

ASIA MARKETS By MarketWatch and Associated Press Hang Seng tumbles nearly 2.5%; Nikkei falls about 2% A man walks by a Huawei logo at a shopping mall in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday. Reuters Asian stock prices fell Thursday, led by tumbling tech stocks, following the arrest of a senior official at Chinese telecom equipment maker Huawei that could derail progress in China-U.S. trade talks. Canadian authorities arrested the chief financial officer of Huawei Technologies for possible extradition to the United States, for allegedly violating sanctions against Iran. Meng Wanzhou was detained in...

item.title: Who is Meng Wanzhou, the Chinese exec wanted by the US? - CNN
item.description:
Who is Meng Wanzhou, the Chinese exec wanted by the US?  CNN

Meng Wanzhou, the CFO of Chinese tech giant Huawei, has kept a low profile for much of her career. Now she's at the center of a geopolitical drama between the world's two largest economies. The 46-year-old executive was arrested Saturday in Canada, and faces extradition to the United States. After news of her arrest broke late Wednesday, Meng's face was splashed across the internet. Meng is the daughter of Huawei's billionaire founder, Ren Zhangfei, and her case threatens to ramp up tensions between Washington and Beijing. "The fact that this is Ren's daughter and a very senior official in ...

item.title: BT removing Huawei equipment from parts of 4G network - The Guardian
item.description:
BT removing Huawei equipment from parts of 4G network  The Guardian

BT has confirmed it is removing Huawei equipment from key areas of its 4G network after concerns were raised about the Chinese firm‚Äôs presence in critical telecoms infrastructure. The company said the removals were merely the continuation of a policy which began when it purchased the mobile phone carrier EE in 2015, to ensure that both parts of the combined network ran on the same technology. Many peripheral parts of BT and EE‚Äôs systems still run on Huawei equipment, and there were no plans to alter that. Governments in the US, New Zealand and Australia have already moved to block the use o...

item.description:
üá®üá¶üá®üá≥Canada arrests CFO of Chinese telecoms giant Huawei | Al Jazeera English  Al Jazeera English

Meng Wanzhou, chief financial officer of Chinese telecoms giant Huawei, has been arrested in Vancouver, Canada on December 1 and faces extradition to the United States. "She is sought for extradition by the United States, and a bail hearing has been set for Friday," Canada's justice ministry said, adding it could not provide further details due to a publication ban that was sought by and granted to Meng. Earlier this year, US media reported that the US was investigating Huawei for violating sanctions on Iran by selling network equipment to the country. Al Jazeera's Adrian Brown reports from...

item.title: Report: Huawei‚Äôs troubles may be worsening as Japan and British Telecom weigh bans - Fast Company
item.description:
Report: Huawei‚Äôs troubles may be worsening as Japan and British Telecom weigh bans  Fast Company

Things are getting even worse for Chinese telecom giant Huawei. British Telecom, one of the UK‚Äôs largest internet providers, said this week it will not use Huawei‚Äôs equipment in its 5G mobile network when it is rolled out in the UK, according to the BBC. Japan is also reportedly limiting the use of Huawei components in government-backed networks. These moves date back to 2012, when Huawei and its rival Chinese telecom, ZTE Corp, were the subjects of a U.S. Congressional investigation into whether their equipment could pose a threat to U.S. security. Congress issued a report concluding that ...

item.description:

item.title: Japan government to halt buying Huawei, ZTE equipment: sources - Reuters
item.description:
Japan government to halt buying Huawei, ZTE equipment: sources  Reuters

Japan plans to ban government purchases of equipment from China's Huawei Technologies Co Ltd and ZTE Corp to beef up its defenses against intelligence leaks and cyber attacks, sources told Reuters. Chinese tech companies are under intense scrutiny from Washington and some prominent allies over ties to the Chinese government, driven by concerns they could be used by Beijing for spying. A government ban in Japan will come after Huawei has already been locked out of the U.S. market and after Australia and New Zealand have blocked it from building 5G networks. Huawei has repeatedly insisted Bei...

item.title: BT to strip China's Huawei from core networks, limit 5G access - Reuters
item.description:
BT to strip China's Huawei from core networks, limit 5G access  Reuters

Britain's BT Group said on Wednesday it was removing Huawei Technologies' equipment from the core of its existing 3G and 4G mobile operations and would not use the Chinese company in central parts of the next network. New Zealand and Australia have stopped telecom operators using Huawei's equipment in new 5G networks because they are concerned about possible Chinese government involvement in their communications infrastructure. Huawei, the world's biggest network equipment maker ahead of Ericsson and Nokia, has said Beijing has no influence over its operations. BT said Huawei's equipment ha...

item.title: Oppo R17 Pro Review: The World's Fastest Charging Phone - Forbes
item.description:
Oppo R17 Pro Review: The World's Fastest Charging Phone  Forbes

The Oppo R17 Pro with its gorgeous gradient-colored back. Most Chinese smartphone brands nowadays pump out four, five, or six devices a year, to a market that‚Äôs already beyond saturate. Many of these manufacturers barely differentiate each of these handsets, so much so that they tend to get lost in the noise and are forgotten quickly. However Oppo, for the most part, has done a solid job of making sure each release is worth covering, with at least one head-turning feature. The Find X, for example, was an absolute stunner in design and craftsmanship and will likely end up in one of the top t...

item.title: Huawei Executive's Arrest Threatens To Derail Company's Global Ambitions - Forbes
item.description:

Attendees stand at the Huawei Technologies booth at the Mobile World Congress Shanghai on June 28, 2018. (Photo: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg) The arrest of a senior executive at telecom equipment supplier Huawei Technologies will likely give rise to more security concerns in other countries closely allied with the U.S. and jeopardize the company‚Äôs future revenue streams. Huawei‚Äôs Chief Financial Officer Meng Wanzhou, who is also the daughter of the company‚Äôs founder Ren Zhengfei, was detained in Vancouver and faces possible extradition to the U.S. While the charges against Meng haven‚Äôt been specif...

item.title: BT to remove Huawei hardware from 4G network amid fears of Chinese spying - The Telegraph
item.description:
BT to remove Huawei hardware from 4G network amid fears of Chinese spying  The Telegraph

BT will remove Huawei hardware from its core 4G network within the next two years amid concerns over China's influence on national telecoms infrastructure. The decision comes as governments increase their scrutiny of Huawei equipment ahead of rolling out 5G, the next generation mobile communication technology that promise faster download speeds and better connections. A spokesman said that Huawei devices will be removed ‚Äúfrom the core of our 3G and 4G networks as part of our network architecture principles in place since 2006‚Äù. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre applying these same principles to our current request fo...

item.title: Japan may move to restrict Huawei, ZTE from government use - MarketWatch
item.description:
Japan may move to restrict Huawei, ZTE from government use  MarketWatch

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL By Mayumi Negishi U.S. and allies claim Chinese telecoms engage in cyberspying The Japanese government may effectively ban Huawei as soon as Monday. Reuters TOKYO ‚Äî Japan is moving ahead with changes to its procurement guidelines that could restrict government use of Chinese telecommunications-equipment companies Huawei Technologies Co. and ZTE Corp., following American accusations that the firms engage in cyberspying. On Friday, government officials said a meeting was planned for as soon as Monday at which they would discuss possible ways to lower the risk of infilt...

item.title: Opinion: Huawei arrest creates concerns in Silicon Valley as well as abroad - MarketWatch
item.description:
Opinion: Huawei arrest creates concerns in Silicon Valley as well as abroad  MarketWatch

MARKETWATCH FIRST TAKE By Therese Poletti Detainment of Huawei CFO creates concerns for U.S. suppliers as well as clouds trade dispute with China China‚Äôs Huawei sells more than a quarter of the world‚Äôs telecom equipment. Reuters The arrest of Huawei Technologies Co.‚Äôs chief financial officer is sure to put a crimp in the Trump administration‚Äôs trade truce with China, as that highly sensitive issue gets more so, but investors are nervous about the impact the whole saga will have on Silicon Valley and abroad. On Thursday, shares of many chip and fiber-optic companies fell, helping fuel a mark...

item.title: A Second Silicon Valley In China Rattles The U.S. Tech Elite And DC - Think Huawei - Forbes
item.description:
A Second Silicon Valley In China Rattles The U.S. Tech Elite And DC - Think Huawei  Forbes

Huawei retail shop in Beijing Ongoing frictions over China‚Äôs growing technology innovation edge are highlighted by the U.S. recent arrest of Huawei‚Äôs CFO who is the daughter of the founder. The widespread news of charges against Huawei ‚Äî whether for questionable financial transactions or violations of Iran sanctions ‚Äî underscore the increasing power and impact that Chinese tech companies now have in the West. Chinese leaders such as Huawei have become a competitive challenge for the U.S. tech elite. Huawei is the world‚Äôs largest smartphone maker, not Apple. The backdrop is the rise of Chi...

item.title: China's Huawei pledges $2 billion to allay British security fears: sources - Reuters
item.description:
China's Huawei pledges $2 billion to allay British security fears: sources  Reuters

China's Huawei [HWT.UL] will spend $2 billion as part of efforts to address security issues raised in a British government report earlier this year, sources with knowledge of the matter said on Friday. Huawei, the world's biggest producer of telecoms equipment, faces intense scrutiny in the West over its ties to the Chinese government and concerns its equipment could be used by Beijing for spying. The company has repeatedly denied the allegations. The British government report, signed off by Britain's GCHQ spy agency and released in July, found that technical and supply-chain issues with eq...

item.title: EE signs deal with Chinese smartphone firm in bid for UK's first 5G coverage - The Telegraph
item.description:
EE signs deal with Chinese smartphone firm in bid for UK's first 5G coverage  The Telegraph

BT's mobile network arm EE will launch what is expected to be the first 5G smartphone on UK networks early next year, signing a deal with Chinese smartphone minnow OnePlus for its upcoming 5G phone. The network operator is planning to launch the latest generation of wireless technology from 2019 in 16 cities in the UK. The deal with OnePlus will mean the smartphone maker will be among the first to secure network coverage for its new phone on the fifth-generation network. While countries like Japan, South Korea and China have been making advances on 5G technology, EE is the first network so ...

item.title: Arrest of Huawei 'heiress' throws rare spotlight on family - Reuters
item.description:
Arrest of Huawei 'heiress' throws rare spotlight on family  Reuters

Like many top Chinese executives, Meng Wanzhou is a mysterious figure even in her home country, but the 46-year-old chief financial officer of Huawei Technologies had been widely tipped to one day take the helm of the tech giant her father founded. That was until her shock arrest in Canada at the request of U.S. authorities on Wednesday, a move that has entangled her in the protracted diplomatic tensions between Washington and Beijing. Her fate is now uncertain. A source familiar with the matter told Reuters the arrest stems from Huawei Technologies Co Ltd's [HWT.UL] alleged violation of U....

item.title: BT to strip Huawei equipment from its core 4G network - Financial Times
item.description:
BT to strip Huawei equipment from its core 4G network  Financial Times

BT will strip Huawei equipment out of its core 4G network within two years to bring its mobile phone business in line with an internal policy to keep the Chinese company‚Äôs equipment at the periphery of telecoms infrastructure. Governments around the world have become increasingly wary of Huawei‚Äôs presence in critical national telecoms infrastructure, especially as they prepare for auctions for 5G, a superfast service that will enable a new generation of digital products and services. The US, Australia and New Zealand have moved to block the use of the Chinese company‚Äôs 5G equipment on secur...

item.title: U.S. Takes Aim at Huawei - The Wall Street Journal
item.description:
U.S. Takes Aim at Huawei  The Wall Street Journal

The Trump administration‚Äôs efforts to extradite the chief financial officer of China‚Äôs Huawei Technologies Co. over criminal charges mark the start of an even more aggressive phase in the technology rivalry between the U.S. and China and will increase pressure on Washington‚Äôs allies to shun the telecommunications company. Armed with a U.S. extradition request, Canadian authorities arrested Meng Wanzhou on Dec. 1, the same day as President Trump was holding a summit with Chinese counterpart President Xi Jinping. But White House officials said Mr. Trump had no advance knowledge of the arrest,...

item.title: Apple Delays 5G iPhone Release - International Business Times
item.description:
Apple Delays 5G iPhone Release  International Business Times

Apple does not plan to jump on the bandwagon and release a 5G-ready iPhone next year, when the next-generation network starts to become available to the public. The Cupertino giant reportedly plans to hold off until 2020 before launching a 5G-capable iPhone even though rivals like Samsung Electronics are preparing to take advantage of the high-speed phone services debuting in 2019, people familiar with Apple‚Äôs plans told Bloomberg on Monday. Since early this year, many companies have been teasing about the launch of 5G networks next year. Smartphone makers have also chimed in, promising con...

item.title: The Latest: Huawei awaits 'right conclusion' in CFO's arrest - The Associated Press
item.description:
The Latest: Huawei awaits 'right conclusion' in CFO's arrest  The Associated Press

WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî The Latest on the arrest of an executive of Chinese telecoms equipment maker Huawei Technologies (all times local): 11:45 p.m. Chinese telecommunications giant Huawei says it has "every confidence that the Canadian and U.S. legal systems will reach the right conclusion" over the arrest of one of its top executives in Canada. Huawei released a brief statement Saturday in China following a bail hearing in Vancouver for Meng Wanzou, its chief financial officer and the daughter of its founder. She faces possible extradition to the U.S, where officials allege that Huawei used a...

item.title: Huawei: Chinese media accuses US of 'hooliganism' over Meng Wanzhou arrest - The Guardian
item.description:
Huawei: Chinese media accuses US of 'hooliganism' over Meng Wanzhou arrest  The Guardian

Chinese media have lashed out at the US over the arrest of senior Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou, accusing the country of using ‚Äúhooliganism‚Äù to suppress the Chinese telecom giant at the centre of what is turning into a major diplomatic incident. State-run China Daily said the arrest of Huawei‚Äôs chief financial officer appeared to be part of US efforts to contain the company, which is the world‚Äôs largest telecoms equipment provider, as well as its second-largest mobile phone maker. ‚ÄúOne thing that is undoubtedly true and proven is the US is trying to do whatever it can to contain Huawei‚Äôs ex...

item.title: The Huawei Mate 20 Pro's Epic Battery Life Has Spoiled Me For Other Phones - Forbes
item.description:
The Huawei Mate 20 Pro's Epic Battery Life Has Spoiled Me For Other Phones  Forbes

The Huawei Mate 20 Pro has a 4,200mAh battery. Like the majority of people living in Hong Kong, I own a portable battery pack that resides in my bag full time, ready to be called upon whenever my phone is low on power. For years, that meant Saturday and Sunday evenings ‚Äî times when I‚Äôve usually been out and about all day. In Hong Kong ‚Äî and safe to assume other big cities ‚Äî it becomes almost like instinct: sit down for coffee or dinner in the late afternoon or evening? Pull out the portable battery pack unless you want the phone to die before you call it a night. Looking around, I often see...

item.title: Arrest Shakes Huawei as Global Skepticism of Its Business Grows - The New York Times
item.description:
Arrest Shakes Huawei as Global Skepticism of Its Business Grows  The New York Times

It is one of China‚Äôs proudest corporate success stories, a colossus in cutting-edge technology that elbowed out Western rivals to become the biggest supplier of the hardware that connects our modern world. Now, all around the globe, the walls are going up for Huawei. The United States, which for years has considered the Chinese telecommunications giant a security threat, aimed a straight shot at the company‚Äôs leadership when it secured the arrest, in Canada, of Huawei‚Äôs chief financial officer. But lately, Huawei‚Äôs setbacks have come on multiple fronts, from New Zealand and Australia to Bri...

item.title: Smartphone Makers Adopting 5G Tech Next Year Revealed - International Business Times
item.description:
Smartphone Makers Adopting 5G Tech Next Year Revealed  International Business Times

All Android smartphone makers are going to release 5G-ready mobile devices next year, according to Qualcomm President Cristiano Amon. At Qualcomm‚Äôs Snapdragon Technology Summit in Hawaii this past Tuesday, Amon disclosed to CNET in an interview that all Android vendors are expected to launch flagship devices with 5G support by the end of 2019. ‚ÄúWhen we get to exactly this time of year one year from now we will see every [handset maker] on the Android ecosystem, their flagship across all U.S. carriers will be a 5G device,‚Äù Amon said. ‚ÄúEvery Android vendor is working on 5G right now.‚Äù It‚Äôs no...
